The Australian timber merchant found that if he wanted to buy sawn oregon overseas, whether from the United States of America or from Canada, he had bo do so through a member of the combine. If he were dissatisfied with the quality of the timber that he was receiving from a Canadian concern with which he was in the habit of dealing, and endeavoured to divert his custom to the United States of America, he was boycotted; no firm wanted his business, and he was forced back to his original supplier, from whom he had to accept whatever was sent to him. That was one factor. Another factor was the desire of the Australian sawmiller to escape from the control of the overseas sawn timber combine. The result has been that the Australian builder or architect now has an equal opportunity with the American and Canadian users of timber to obtain the best cuts.

speech.para: Progress reported.

subdebateinfo.title: Referendum Pamphlet : Contracts for Addressing Wrappers

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: . - The day before yesterday, I asked a question in connexion with the work of addressing wrappers for the literature that is to be distributed in connexion with the forthcoming referen dum. The answer that I received appeared to be satisfactory, but information that I have since had supplied to me would make it appear that it was not. I do not know whether the Government is aware of the facts. Some millions of wrappers have to be addressed, and this involves a good deal of clerical work, which has been contracted out to business colleges. In response to my request to be supplied with particulars of what was being done, I have received the following communication from the secretary of the Federated Clerks Union of Australia: -

quote.para: Mr. Katz and myself interviewed the Principal of Hassett's College, concerning his students being employed on this work for the Commonwealth Government and he informed us that he was in receipt of payment from the Common wealth Government for addressing the wrappers for pamphlets and was under no obligation to pay the students for performing the work. He stated that he intended to give them a " Christmas Bo?: " as pocket money when the work had been finished. He subsequently communicated with me by telephone and asked how he could get over the difficulty and I informed him that in the first place he would have to pay these girls the commercial clerks' wages board rates, namely, 21s. 6d. per week of 43 hours. Even if that was agreed to, he would not be complying with the determination as he would not have sufficient seniors to employ a large number of juniors. As this matter affects members of the federation, the general president (Mr. A. E. Monk) and general secretary (Mr. Katz) have taken it up and we trust that you will pursue same further, as these students are still paying for their lessons and are employed without legal rates being paid.

speech.para: The Commonwealth has contracted to have this work done, and has paid these business colleges a certain sum for doing it. It made no inquiries, and imposed no conditions, probably believing that legal formalities would be observed. These colleges are very large establishments, and are finely run. My daughter * and the daughters of others who are sent to them to be taught shorthand and typing are doing this work at night and receiving no payment for it. I am certain that the Minister will realize the seriousness of the matter, and that the Government does not wish to be accused of "sweating", as it would be if what I have alleged is permitted to be done. I shall say no more until the Government has had an opportunity to make inquiries.

talk.start.para: . -I assure the honorable member that the fullest investigation -will be made into the matter that he has raised, and that a further statement will be made upon it later.

speech.para: Question, resolved in the affirmative.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated: -

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

quote.para: Has a requestyet been received for on impartial tribunal to investigate the Freer case; if so, will he indicate what attitude the Government intends to adopt?

talk.start.para: - A letter has been received from Mrs. Freer's solicitor, and is at present under consideration,
asked the Attorney-General, upon notice -

quote.para: Has he or his department received a letter from Mrs. Freer's counsel requesting an independent inquiry into her case; ifso, has the Cabinet considered the request, and what is its decision?

talk.start.para: - A letter has been received from Mrs. Freer's solicitor, and is at. present under consideration.

subdebateinfo.title: Northern Territory: Public Works Contracts - Mining Grants

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Interior, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that, owing to the Public Works Department, Darwin, Northern Territory, arranging for the supply of gravel to the department without first obtaining the contractor's signature to the department's regulation form for contracts which specify a deposit and a declaration by the contractor that he has paid all his workmen before be receives payment himself, some workmen have not received their wages from one of these contractors ?

Is it a fact that, when Mr. West, head of the Public Works Department, was approached by the union secretary on behalf of the workmen, he stated that nothing could be done by the department to recover the men's wages, and is it also a fact that the same contractor is again employed by the Public Works Department, through another contractor, on wellsinking?
If the facts are as stated, will the Minister take steps to see that the men's wages arc paid, and that in future all work be carried out by the department instead of letting it out by contract?

talk.start.para: - Inquiries are being made, and replies will be furnished to the honorable member at the earliest possible date.
asked the Minister for the Interior, upon notice -

item.para: -Will he explain why a grant of £299 was made to Alluvial Gold Limited, when the company had never, registered any holdings-?
Are the directors of this company F. G. and E. H. Pratten and A. P. Penman; if so, are the first two persons related to a former Minister for Trade and Customs?
Why was a grant of £988 made to North Australia Mines Limited, when the company had no existing mine holdings?
Has the company any holdings now?
Are the directors of this company E. JR. Hollingdale and Walter Joseph Murray; if. so, is the latter related to the Hon. T. 'G. Murray, M.L.C?
Who are the directors, and what holdings have they registered, of Yemelba Holdings Limited?"
What arrangement for repayment was made for all' grants made in regard to mines in the Northern Territory, and does the Government hold any security in regard to these grants ?
Is it a fact that Sir Samuel Walder, the Honorable T. G. Murray, M.L.C., and Mr. H. W. Lloyd, M.L.A., are directors of various companies to which grants have been made?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: Alluvial Gold Limited was assisted on a £1 for £1 basis in respect of general expenses incurred in carrying out an expert examination of gold and mineral areas in the 'Northern Territory under conditions considered satisfactory to the department. .
The persona named are directors of Alluvial Gold Limited. The department is unaware of the relationship referred to.

At the time the grant was approved, North Australia Mines Limited was the registered holder of gold-mining leases Nos. 788 and 704 union reefs, and subsequently acquired protected lease applications Nos. 1169 and 1170.
No.
The persons named are directors of North Australia Mines Limited. The department is unaware of any such relationship.
Directors' names of Yemelba Holdings Limited are not available, and no holdings are at present registered in name of company. '

The repayment of grants approved for mine development purposes in the Northern Territory is secured by means of. mortgages over the mining leases, liens over the pro- tected lease applications and bills of sale covering all machinery and other chattels owned or held by the respective companies to which the grants are made.
Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade and Customs, upon- notice -

quote.para: What was the total amount of cement imported into Australia during the year ended the 30th June, 1936?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows : -

quote.para: 14,467 tons 1 cwt. (including white, coloured, and special types of cement).

talk.start.para: On the 25th November, the honorable member for Bass (Mr. Barnard) asked the following questions, upon notice : -

item.para: What is the total expenditure under the River Murray Waters Agreement to date?
How much of this cost has been borne by each of the interested States?
How much has been borne by the Federal Government?
What is the estimated cost of the completion of the scheme?

question.para: The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.label: 2 and 3.
item.para: New South Wales, £2,626,601; Victoria, £2,626,601; South Australia, £2,620,601 ; Commonwealth, £2,626,601.

quote.para: Note. - The . above-mentioned particulars refer to the construction of works and do not include amounts expended on the maintenance, operation and. control of completed works and gauging stations, or administrative expenses.

talk.start.para: - On the 18th November, the honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Nock) asked me a question, upon notice, regarding costs of production in coal mines in New South Wales. Inquiries have been made of the Under-Secretary, Mines Department, Sydney, who has supplied the following information : -

item.para: During 1935 a total of 246,697 tons of coal was produced from the small mines in the Northern District (where practically all the small mines in the State are situated), representing 4.34 per cent, of the total, output from the district. Five hundred and fifty-one persons were employed at these small mines during the same 'year, the average production for each person for the year being 429 tons, as. compared with the average production of 653 tons for each person employed at all mines in the Northern District. While it is understood that the wages received by the persons working at small mines vary considerably at different collieries, and that, generally speaking, the amount paid for each ton of coal produced is less at those mines where members of the Miners Federation are not employed, this is a matter not coining within the purview of this department, and statistics relating thereto cannot be supplied.

In view of the fact that, in all coalproducing countries, increasing use 'is being ' mode of mechanical means of producing coal, the suggestion cannot be supported that any disparity in the cost of production at large and small mines in this State is the main cause of mechanization and excessive unemployment among coal-miners.
